greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of ways the first n primes can be partitioned into three sets with equal sums.
comment: It is not true that a(2k+1) is always 0.
reference: Keith F. Lynch, Posting to Math Fun Mailing List, Sep 17 2019.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..102
formula: a(n) > 0 <=> n in { A103208 }, with odd n in { A111320 }. - _Alois P. Heinz_, Sep 19 2019
example: One of the three solutions for n = 10: 3 + 17 + 23 = 2 + 5 + 7 + 29 = 11 + 13 + 19.
maple: s:= proc(n) option remember; `if`(n<2, 0, ithprime(n)+s(n-1)) end:
b:= proc(n, x, y) option remember; `if`(n=1, 1, (p-> (l->
mathematica: b[n_, x_, y_] := b[n, x, y] = If[n == 1, 1, Function[p, Function[l, Sum[If[ p > l[[i]], 0, b[n - 1, Sequence @@ Sort[ReplacePart[l, i -> l[[i]] - p]][[1;; 2]]]], {i, 1, 3}]][{x, y, s[n] - x - y}]][Prime[n]]];
Array[a, 40] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Apr 09 2020, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
program: my(recurse(k,s,p)=if(k==brk, if(s<#q, polcoef(p*q[s+1],m,y)), if(s<=vs[k], self()(k-1, s, p*(1 + y^v[k]))) + if(s>=v[k], self()(k-1, s-v[k], p)) ));
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Sep 19 2019
ext: Corrected and a(30)-a(52) added by _Andrew Howroyd_, Sep 19 2019
